page.title: 12LONGFORGAN - HOUSING -
page.content: Housing in Longforgan is typified by the single storey cottages which line the former Dundee-Perth turnpike road. These cottages were built of sandstone with timber raftered roofs which were originally turfed or thatched, but are nowadays slated, although two examples still exist today on the north side of the village street. Usually the stone walls were whitewashed and internally were of two rooms and date back to the 18th century. In the 19th century some large stone built villas were built, for example, the Croft (1895) with its large stone chimneys, diamond paned glass and receding roofs on each storey. To the southwest of the village is Castle Huntly, built in the mid 18th century in the style of an L-shaped tower house, and also Rossie Priory which is an example of building in the neo-Gothic house style.
